subsection.title: Squares of Monomials
subsection.p: A few special binomial products occur so frequently that it is useful to recognize their forms. This will enable you to write their factored forms directly, without trial and error. To prepare for these special products, we first consider the squares of monomials.
Study the squares of monomials in Example 1. Do you see a quick way to find the product?

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In Example 1a, we doubled the exponent and kept the same base. In Example 1b, we squared the numerical coefficient and doubled the exponent.

statement.p: Why do we double the exponent when we square a power?

answer.p: Because when we multiply powers with the same base, we add the exponents.

statement.p: Find a monomial whose square is 36t^8.

solution.p: When we square a power, we double the exponent, so t^8 is the square of t^4. Because 36 is the square of 6, the monomial we want is 6t^4. To check our result, we square 6t^4 to see that (6t^4)^2=36t^8.

subsection.title: Squares of Binomials
subsection.p:
You can use the distributive law to verify each of the following special products.
(a+b)^2 \amp =(a+b)(a+b) \amp \amp \amp (a-b)^2 \amp =(a-b)(a-b) \amp = a^2+ab+ab+b^2 \amp \amp \amp \amp =a^2-ab-ab+b^2 \amp = a^2+2ab+b^2 \amp \amp \amp \amp =a^2-2ab+b^2

statement.p: Explain why it is NOT true that (a+b)^2=a^2+b^2.

answer.p: Because we must square (a+b) using FOIL.

subsection.p: We can use these results as formulas to compute the square of any binomial.
Of course, you can verify that you will get the same answer for Example 3 if you compute the square by multiplying (2x+3)(2x+3).

subsection.title: Difference of Two Squares
subsection.p: Now consider the product (a+b)(a-b) = a^2 - ab + ab - b^2 In this product, the two middle terms cancel each other, and we are left with a difference of two squares.

statement.p: Explain the difference between (a-b)^2 and a^2-b^2.

answer.p: To simplify (a-b)^2, we must square the binomial.

subsection.title: Factoring Special Products
subsection.p: The three special products we have just studied are useful as patterns for factoring certain polynomials. For factoring, we view the formulas from right to left.

If we recognize one of the special forms, we can use the formula to factor it. Notice that all three special products involve two squared terms, a^2 and b^2, so we first look for two squared terms in our trinomial.

solution.p: This trinomial has two squared terms, x^2 and 144. These terms are a^2 and b^2, so a=x and b=12. We check whether the middle term is equal to 2ab. 2ab=2(x)(12) = 24x This is the correct middle term, so our trinomial has the form (1), with a=x and b=12. Thus, a^2+2ab+b^2 \amp = (a+b)^2 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Replace}~a~\text{by}~x~\text{and}~b~ \text{by}~12.} x^2+24x+144 \amp = (x+12)^2

statement.p: How can we factor a^2- 2ab + b^2?
How can we factor a^2- b^2?

warning.p: The sum of two squares, a^2+b^2, cannot be factored! For example, x^2+16,~~~~~~9x^2+4y^2,~~~~~~\text{and}~~~~~~25y^4+w^4 cannot be factored. You can check, for instance, that x^2+16 \not= (x+4)(x+4).

assemblage.title: Sum of Two Squares
assemblage.p: The sum of two squares, ~a^2+b^2~, cannot be factored.

subsection.p: As always when factoring, we should check first for common factors.

solution.p: Each term has a factor of 2, so we begin by factoring out 2. 98-28x^4+2x^8 = 2(49-14x^4+x^8) The polynomial in parentheses has the form (a-b)^2, with a=7 and b=x^4. The middle term is -2ab=-2(7)(x^4) We use equation (2) to write a^2+2ab+b^2 \amp = (a-b)^2 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Replace}~a~\text{by}~7~\text{and}~b~ \text{by}~x^4.} 49-14x^4+x^8 \amp = (7-x^4)^2 Thus, 98-28x^4+2x^8 = 2(7-x^4)^2
